facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 135 of 1961 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 3, 1961 of the Rajasthan High Court, Jodhpur in Civil Writ Petition No. 1 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 3, 1961, of the Rajasthan High Court, Jodhpur, in Civil Writ Petition No. 1 of 1961.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on April 14, 1961 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-

facts.text: These two connected matters arise out of an order approving a scheme framed under Chap. IV-A of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-These two companynected matters arise out of an order approving a scheme framed under Chap. IV-A of the Motor Vehicles Act, No. IV of 1939,

facts.text: The appellant was plying a bus between Jaipur and Ajmer on a permit granted to him for three years by resolution of the Regional Transport Authority, Jaipur dated December 16/17, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. The appellant was plying a bus between Jaipur and Ajmer on a permit granted to him for three years by resolution of the Regional Transport Authority, Jaipur, dated December 16/17, 1958.

facts.text: In August 1960, the State Government promulgated rules under s. 68-1 of the Act called the Rajasthan State Road Transport Services Development Rules, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In August, 1960, the State Government promulgated rules under s. 68-1 of the Act, called the Rajasthan State Road Transport Services  Development  Rules, 1960  hereinafter called the Rules .

facts.text: A draft scheme was published on September 7, 1960 for taking over the Jaipur-Ajmer route.

anchor.surface_text: A draft scheme was published on September 7, 1960, for taking over the Jaipur-Ajmer route.

facts.text: The appellant made objections to the draft scheme within the time allowed by the notification thereof.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made objections to the draft scheme within the time allowed by the numberification thereof.

facts.text: The State Government appointed the Legal Remembrancer to hear and decide the objections under r. 7 of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government appointed the Legal Remembrancer to hear and decide the objections under r. 7 of the Rules.

facts.text: Some bus operators filed an application under Art. 226 before the Rajasthan High Court challenging the constitutionality of s. 68-D of the Act and the legality of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in the meantime an application was made under Art. 226 by some bus operators before the Rajasthan High Court challenging the companystitutionality of s. 68-D of the Act and the legality of the Rules framed by the State Government.

facts.text: The High Court application was dismissed on November 9, 1960 and held that the officer hearing objections had no power to cancel the draft scheme under r. 7 or s. 68-D(2).

anchor.surface_text: This application was dismissed and the High Court inter alia decided while companysidering r. 7 6  that it was number open to the officer hearing the objections to cancel the draft scheme and seems to have held that there was numbersuch power even under s. 68-D 2  of the Act. This decision was given on November 9, 1960.

facts.text: The draft scheme came up for consideration before the officer on November 21, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The draft scheme came up for companysideration before the officer appointed to hear objections on November 21,, 1960.

facts.text: On November 21, 1960, the appellant's application to give evidence on points of fact was rejected by the officer on the ground that there was no provision in the Rules for recording evidence of witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: An application was made before him that the appellant should be permitted to give evidence on points of fact which were narrated in the application in order that the officer may be in a position to decide the objections justly. This application was rejected by the officer on the ground that there was numberprovision in the Rules for recording of evidence of witnesses.

facts.text: On November 23, 1960, another application was made by the appellant to lead evidence to show that the draft scheme must be rejected in its entirety, contending that the Rajasthan High Court view was incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: The matter then came up for companysideration on November 23, 1960. On that date another application was made in which it was said that the appellant wanted to lead evidence to show that the draft scheme must be rejected in its entirety, and it was companytended that the view taken by the Rajasthan High Court to the effect that it was number open to the officer to cancel a draft scheme was incorrect.

facts.text: The officer rejected the November 23, 1960 application stating he was bound by the decision of the Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This application was also rejected by the officer with the observation that he was bound hand and foot by the decision of the Rajasthan High Court and if there was anything wrong in the interpretation given by the High Court the remedy lay elsewhere.

facts.text: The officer approved the draft scheme by order dated December 7, 1960 after hearing arguments.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the officer gave a hearing to the appellant in the sense that he heard arguments on behalf of the appellant and approved the draft scheme by his order dated December 7, 1960.

facts.text: The approved scheme was published on December 12, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The approved scheme was then published on December 12,1960.

facts.text: On January 9, 1961, the Regional Transport Authority informed the appellant that his permit was cancelled as from January 26, 1961 or such later date from which the buses of Rajasthan State Roadways begin to operate on the route.

anchor.surface_text: On January 9, 1961, the Regional Transport Authority informed the appellant that his permit was cancelled, as from January 26, 1961, or such later date from which the buses of Rajasthan State Roadways begin to operate on the above-mentioned route.

facts.text: The appellant unsuccessfully moved the Rajasthan High Court and his prayer for leave to appeal to this Court was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the appellant unsuccessfully moved the Rajasthan High Court, and his prayer for leave to appeal to this Court was also rejected.

facts.text: The Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for special leave to appeal to this Court which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: The appellant urged that the officer was wrong in holding he had no power to reject the draft scheme in its entirety.

anchor.surface_text: Two main points have been urged before us on behalf of the appellant, namely,  i  the officer was wrong in the view he took that it was number open to him to reject the draft scheme in its entirety,

facts.text: The appellant urged that the officer was wrong in holding that he could not take evidence, whether oral or documentary, under s. 68-D.

anchor.surface_text: ii  the officer was wrong in holding that he companyld number take evidence, whether oral or documentary, and all that he had to do under s. 68-D of the Act was to hear arguments on either side.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the officer was wrong in thinking he had no power to reject the draft scheme altogether under s. 68-D(2).

anchor.surface_text: The officer therefore was wrong in holding that he had numberpower to reject the scheme in the sense that he companyld withhold approval of it altogether, though we may add that he came to that companyclusion because of the earlier decision of the Rajasthan High Court.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the hearing under s. 68-D(2) may include taking of evidence, both oral and documentary.

anchor.surface_text: A hearing before a quasi-judicial authority does number merely mean an argument it may in proper cases include the taking of evidence, both oral and documentary.

facts.text: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside the order approving the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the officer companycerned approving the scheme and direct that the draft scheme be reconsidered by the said officer or such other officer as the State Government may appoint hereafter

facts.text: The Supreme Court directed reconsideration of the draft scheme after giving a proper hearing.

anchor.surface_text: and direct that the draft scheme be reconsidered by the said officer or such other officer as the State Government may appoint hereafter after giving a hearing in the light of the observations we have made above.

issues.text: Whether under s. 68-D(2) of the Motor Vehicles Act and r. 7(6) of the Rules the authority has power to reject the draft scheme in its entirety by refusing to approve it

anchor.surface_text: i the officer was wrong in the view he took that it was number open to him to reject the draft scheme in its entirety, and ii the officer was wrong in holding that he companyld number take evidence, whether oral or documentary, and all that he had to do under s. 68-D of the Act was to hear arguments on either side. It is companytended that in view of these two wrong decisions of the officer his approach to what he had to do in dealing with objections under s. 68-D was quite incorrect.

issues.text: What is the scope of the hearing under s. 68-D(2) of the Motor Vehicles Act? Whether it includes taking of evidence oral or documentary or is confined to arguments?

anchor.surface_text: Re. ii The next question is the scope of the hearing under s. 68- D 2 . The officer has held that the scope of the hearing is companyfined only to hearing of arguments and numbermore, and that is why he rejected the prayer of the appellant for leading evidence, whether oral or documentary. Now it has been held by this Court in Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation that a State Government acts as a quasi-judicial tribunal when giving a hearing under s. 68-D.

arguments.claim: Under s.68-D(2), State Government may approve or modify but implies power not to approve draft scheme at all

anchor.surface_text: What s. 68-D 2  provides is that after hearing the parties, the State Government may approve or modify the draft scheme. This in our opinion clearly implies that the authority ... has the power also, if it so thinks fit, not to approve the scheme at all.

arguments.claim: s.68-E cancellation applies only to approved schemes under s.68-D(3), not drafts

anchor.surface_text: When s. 68-E speaks of cancellation it refers to a scheme already approved under s. 68-D 3 , and in that context the word cancellation is properly used.

arguments.claim: r.7(6) in similar terms to s.68-D(2); 'shall' does not curtail power to not approve

anchor.surface_text: As for r. 7 6  of the Rules it is in similar terms as s. 68- D 2  and must therefore mean what we have said above with respect to s. 68-D 2 .

arguments.claim: True position under s.68-D(2) and r.7(6) allows withholding approval (conceded)

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor-General who appeared for the State of Rajasthan did not contest that what we have said above was the true position in s. 68-D 2  and r. 7 6 .

arguments.claim: Hearing under s.68-D(2) as quasi-judicial includes taking evidence oral and documentary (citing Gullapalli precedent)

anchor.surface_text: Now it has been held by this Court in Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation that a State Government acts as a quasi-judicial tribunal when giving a hearing under s. 68-D.

arguments.claim: Purpose of hearing is to verify if scheme meets s.68-C criteria; requires materials/evidence

anchor.surface_text: The purpose of the hearing is that the State Government has to satisfy itself that the opinion of the State Transport Undertaking formed under s. 68-C ... is correct.

arguments.claim: Due to wrong approach on both points, no effective/proper hearing under s.68-D(2); approval vitiated

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that in view of these two wrong decisions of the officer his approach to what he had to do in dealing with objections under s. 68-D was quite incorrect., with the result that there was no effective hearing

court_response_anchor.surface_text: it was number open to the parties to produce evidence before him and they were companyfined only to submit their arguments on the basis of the draft

arguments.court_reasoning: Wrong approach resulted in no proper hearing; vitiates approval

arguments.claim: State Government controls production of evidence: relevance, extent, reasonable opportunity

anchor.surface_text: It will therefore be for the State Government ... to decide ... whether firstly the evidence is necessary and relevant ... it would have all the powers of controlling the giving and the recording of evidence that any court has.

holdings.text: Under s. 68-D(2), the State Government has the power, after hearing objections, not to approve the draft scheme at all, in which case it stands rejected.

anchor.surface_text: What s. 68-D 2  provides is that after hearing the parties, the State Government may approve or modify the draft scheme. This in our opinion clearly implies that the authority which has to approve or modify the scheme has the power also, if it so thinks fit, not to approve the scheme at all. What is before the. State Government under s. 68-D  2  is a draft scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'may approve or modify' implies option not to approve; draft scheme is mere proposal until approved; distinguishes from cancellation under s.68-E.

holdings.text: Rule 7(6) of the Rules is in similar terms to s.68-D(2) and carries the same meaning, including power not to approve; use of 'shall' does not curtail statutory power.

anchor.surface_text: As for r. 7 6  of the Rules it is in similar terms as s. 68- D 2  and must therefore mean what we have said above with respect to s. 68-D 2 . If, however, by the use of the word shall in r. 7 6  in place of the word may which appears in s. 68-D 2  the intention is to curtail the power of the officer hearing the objections, the rule would be bad as going beyond what is provided in s. 68-D 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction with parent section; 'shall' dictated by grammar, not limiting 'may' in statute.

holdings.text: The hearing under s.68-D(2) before the State Government acting as quasi-judicial authority may include taking of evidence, both oral and documentary, if necessary.

anchor.surface_text: Now it has been held by this Court in Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  1  that a State Government acts as a quasi-judicial tribunal when giving a hearing under s. 68-D. The purpose of the hearing is that the State Government has to satisfy itself that the opinion of the State Transport Undertaking formed under s. 68-C,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent (Gullapalli); purposive: to verify s.68-C criteria requires materials beyond arguments.

holdings.text: Production of evidence, oral or documentary, is comprehended within the hearing under s.68-D(2), subject to control by the authority on relevance and extent.

anchor.surface_text: In order therefore to arrive at the conclusion that the draft scheme provides for a transport service of this nature, the State Government as a quasi-judicial authority may require materials to come to that conclusion A hearing before a quasi-judicial authority does not merely mean an argument it may in proper cases include the taking of evidence, both oral and documentary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary for just conclusion on objections; authority controls like a court to prevent abuse.

holdings.text: The officer's wrong approach on power to reject and scope of hearing resulted in no proper hearing under s.68-D(2), vitiating the approval of the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have said above the approach of the officer in this case was wrong on both the points. He was wrong in his view that it was not open to him to reject the scheme in toto and withhold approval altogether. He was also wrong in the view that it was not open to him to take evidence,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Errors on both issues denied effective hearing, violating natural justice.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; order approving scheme set aside; draft scheme to be reconsidered after proper hearing.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the officer concerned approving the scheme and direct that the draft scheme be reconsidered by the said officer or such other officer as the State Government may appoint hereafter after giving a hearing in the light of the observations we have made above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Remedy for procedural defect is remand for fresh consideration.

precedents.citation: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  1  1959 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 319

anchor.surface_text: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  1  1959 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 319 service. In order therefore to arrive at the conclusion that the draft scheme provides for a transport service of this nature, the State Government as a quasi-judicial authority may require materials to come to that conclusion A hearing before a quasi-judicial authority does not merely mean an argument it may in proper cases include the taking of evidence, both oral and documentary.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the officer concerned approving the scheme and direct that the draft scheme be reconsidered by the said officer or such other officer as the State Government may appoint hereafter after giving a hearing in the light of the observations we have made above.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; officer's order approving the scheme set aside; draft scheme directed to be reconsidered after proper hearing under s. 68-D(2)
directions: draft scheme be reconsidered by the said officer or such other officer as the State Government may appoint hereafter after giving a hearing in the light of the observations we have made above

edges.explanation: h1 directly addresses whether authority has power to reject draft scheme under s.68-D(2)

anchor.surface_text: What s. 68-D 2  provides is that after hearing the parties, the State Government may approve or modify the draft scheme. This in our opinion clearly implies that the authority which has to approve or modify the scheme has the power also, if it so thinks fit, not to approve the scheme at all. What is before the. State Government under s. 68-D  2  is a draft scheme.

We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the officer concerned approving the scheme and direct that the draft scheme be reconsidered by the said officer or such other officer as the State Government may appoint hereafter after giving a hearing in the light of the observations we have made above.

anchor.surface_text: As for r. 7 6  of the Rules it is in similar terms as s. 68- D 2  and must therefore mean what we have said above with respect to s. 68-D 2 . If, however, by the use of the word shall in r. 7 6  in place of the word may which appears in s. 68-D 2  the intention is to curtail the power of the officer hearing the objections, the rule would be bad as going beyond what is provided in s. 68-D 2 .

We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the officer concerned approving the scheme and direct that the draft scheme be reconsidered by the said officer or such other officer as the State Government may appoint hereafter after giving a hearing in the light of the observations we have made above.

anchor.surface_text: Now it has been held by this Court in Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  1  that a State Government acts as a quasi-judicial tribunal when giving a hearing under s. 68-D. The purpose of the hearing is that the State Government has to satisfy itself that the opinion of the State Transport Undertaking formed under s. 68-C,

We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the officer concerned approving the scheme and direct that the draft scheme be reconsidered by the said officer or such other officer as the State Government may appoint hereafter after giving a hearing in the light of the observations we have made above.

anchor.surface_text: In order therefore to arrive at the conclusion that the draft scheme provides for a transport service of this nature, the State Government as a quasi-judicial authority may require materials to come to that conclusion A hearing before a quasi-judicial authority does not merely mean an argument it may in proper cases include the taking of evidence, both oral and documentary.

We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the officer concerned approving the scheme and direct that the draft scheme be reconsidered by the said officer or such other officer as the State Government may appoint hereafter after giving a hearing in the light of the observations we have made above.
